title: Information disclosure
vulnerability_information:
Vulnerability tested on:- Brave	1.29.81 Chromium: 93.0.4577.82 (Official Build) (64-bit)
Vulnerability description:- For security measures and for privacy purposes, Brave has the ability to open a normal tab of the Brave when we navigate to: `chrome://wallet`, `chrome://history` etc. due to the reason that Tor should be blocking privileged URIs like `file:///`, `chrome://` etc. When we open local storage URIs or the Data URIs, it is blocking. So, we can say that TOR in Brave protects users from opening anything privileged in the browser.
But there is some weird case for: `chrome://downloads` and `brave://inspect/#devices`. Both can be dangerous when there is a UXSS present there because it can get to know about the data. The `brave://device-log/` looks interesting too, why do we see the device log of brave in the TOR Network in the Brave? 

Steps to reproduce:
1. Open Brave with TOR
2. Navigate to `brave://inspect/#devices`

Expected behavior?
--> When we are doing device debugging, it should have opened normal Brave and shouldn't open the privileged URI in the TOR session itself. Open `chrome://bookmarks` and `chrome://history`

Actual behavior?
--> It opens the debugging session inside the protected tor session.

Suggestions?
--> We should block `chrome://downloads`,  `brave://inspect/#devices`, `brave://device-log/` etc. and when somebody tries to navigate to those URIs, a normal Brave session should be started like we do for `chrome://history` as it keeps TOR away from personal information inside the brave URIs.

## Impact

Information disclosure.

activities.message: Have you found a way for a website to get access to the information displayed on these pages?

Thank you very much for your swift response. :)

This is a partial bug but one can access data on those pages if they find UXSS or such cases. But no, I don't have any such cases but requires a patch. But yes, I have found an interesting case. Navigation from Network protocol to `brave://`.

> This is a partial bug but one can access data on those pages if they find UXSS or such cases.

We would treat a UXSS as high priority whether or not it is in Tor mode, so I don't think we'd consider a user accessing these pages in Tor mode a bug.

> I have found an interesting case. Navigation from Network protocol to brave://.

That does sound like a bug, can you share the details?

Hello,

>  We would treat a UXSS as high priority whether or not it is in Tor mode

It was an example that UXSS can access data from another tab or can execute JS there. There can be other ways too.

> so I don't think we'd consider a user accessing these pages in Tor mode a bug.

Fine. No issues. Then, we should be allowing users to open `chrome://history` in the **TOR Network**, yes? :) If yes, we require a change that the Brave will allow `chrome://history`, `chrome://wallet` etc URIs to open in the **TOR Network** and not just `chrome://device-log` etc. :) But anyway, feel free to close this case if you don't see a bug, we should make it public then. If you still think this isn't the case of the bug then, please allow other URIs to open inside the TOR network especially URIs of history inside the **TOR Network**. The next argument will be that in a **TOR Network**, your data should be cleared when you close the browser, yes? Then, open `chrome://downloads` inside the **TOR Network** why isn't that cleared? Why is the data of the brave accessible in the **TOR Network**? The interesting thing is here:
{F1456704}
See that it is showing the URL from where the file was downloaded in the TOR network which is actually the history of the Brave browser, yes? 
Steps to reproduce:
1. Visit [Download] in the Normal Brave browser and not **TOR Network**
2. I hope step 1 asked you the path to save now, save it anywhere
3. Open Brave with **TOR Network**
4. Navigate to `chrome://downloads`

Argument: Wait. Why are we seeing personal downloads of Brave browser inside TOR network which is completely **separate** from the **brave** browser, this is a violation because, in the TOR network, you shouldn't be able to see the history, downloads, etc data of the browser of the **Brave Browser** and due to this reason when you try to navigate to the `chrome://history`, it will open the Brave browser and not the **open it for you inside the "TOR Network"**. Now, let's disclose some more personal data here. We are obviously given the URL from where the file was downloaded just after the name of the file inside the chrome://downloads, why that URL is visible inside the TOR network? 
**Don't we have any privacy that: Brave browser shouldn't access the history/downloads of TOR and also TOR shouldn't access data of the Brave browser?**

I hope I was able to clarify why the issue requires a patch there.

> That does sound like a bug, can you share the details?

Please find the video PoC attached:
{F1456705}

Feel free to provide consent to make the vulnerability public.

Thanks!

[Download]: https://docs.oracle.com/javase/tutorialJWS/samples/deployment/dynamictree_webstartJWSProject/dynamictree_webstart.jnlp

> Why are we seeing personal downloads of Brave browser inside TOR network which is completely separate from the brave browser

The guarantee that private browsing windows and Tor windows give users is that the browsing history that takes place in these private windows will not be visible outside of that window. So in this example:

1. Download a file in a normal window (say `normal.txt`).
2. Open a Tor window.
3. Download a different file in that Tor window (say `tor.txt`).
4. Open `brave://downloads` in the normal window.
5. Open `brave://downloads` in the Tor window.

You will see only `normal.txt` in the normal window download history. You will see both `normal.txt` and `tor.txt` in the Tor window's download history. Once the Tor window is closed, the `tor.txt` entry is lost.

That's the expected behavior and as far as I can tell, it's working as expected.

Private windows and Tor windows aren't trying to hide the download history from normal windows.

> Please find the video PoC attached:

Dragging a text URL into the tar bar is equivalent to copy/pasting the URL into the URL bar, or typing it by hand into the URL bar. No referrer/opener information is leaked to the original page. We consider these user-initiated navigations and so they are not meant to be blocked.

> It was an example that UXSS can access data from another tab or can execute JS there. There can be other ways too.

If you can find an example of such a way, we would be happy to look at it and review it.

> Private windows and Tor windows aren't trying to hide the download history from normal windows.

Why you can't open "chrome://history" but "chrome://download" in the **TOR Network**? If that's not the problem, you must allow users to access "chrome://history" inside the **TOR Network**. Why aren't you allowing Data URIs, Local storage URIs too then? Allow them as well inside the TOR network as you're allowing users to open "chrome://downloads" inside the TOR Network. 

**Request for a public disclosure**.

> Dragging a text URL into the tar bar is equivalent to copy/pasting the URL into the URL bar, or typing it by hand into the URL bar. No referrer/opener information is leaked to the original page. We consider these user-initiated navigations and so they are not meant to be blocked.

That's why, I didn't make a report of this case as I was aware that writing manually and selecting the text is normal. There was a Chromium bug related to this. Else I should have sent the report to Brave team so far. The case is also in Chromium too and Brave has same codebase.

> If you can find an example of such a way, we would be happy to look at it and review it.

We should better allow "chrome://history" inside the TOR Network that will be reasonable, yes? We should allow chrome://wallet inside the TOR as well. Why should we initiate an extra process of brave? :)

> You will see only normal.txt in the normal window download history. You will see both normal.txt and tor.txt in the Tor window's download history. Once the Tor window is closed, the tor.txt entry is lost.


Anything opened in the TOR should be cleared and shouldn't be present after the process is closed, accepted. But point here is: **Why are you allowing to open chrome://downloads "inside TOR network"?** 

Why do you not allow users to open:
Chrome://bookmarks
Chrome://wallet
Chrome://history
Chrome://help
inside the TOR network? What's the reason behind it? Would you mind telling the reason why it is biased?

Closing the case and requesting team to make this case public as this isn't a vulnerability as per the team. Summary for this case: Commonly, we aren't allowed to access the data of the Brave browser inside the TOR network as it is a privacy violation that's what the reason is Brave with TOR doesn't allow you to open the chrome://history inside a TOR network and also, it won't allow you to open your wallet inside the TOR network but yes, TOR network can violate the privacy and see the downloads of your Brave browser and also a **Tor network** is permitted to perform the device-debugging of the device attached. By this, we should conclude that this was a privacy violation where the TOR network took the past data as well as history (from which location the file was downloaded) inside it's network and unfortunately, the TOR network didn't behave as chrome://history when navigating to chrome://downloads due to which, we were counting this as a bug.
Spoke to the Tor team and this is working as intended. Note that `chrome://` URLs shown in Tor windows are local, so they aren't sent over the Tor network at all.
If they aren't sent over the TOR network, the "chrome://history" should be allowed and you must also allow the local storage URIs then. Why aren't they allowed?

The reason `brave://history` is opened in normal window is that private windows (and therefore Tor windows) inherit the history from normal windows, but don't add anything to the history.

If we were to open `brave://history` in the Tor window, it might confuse users into thinking that their private browsing history has been recorded on their local disk.

> If we were to open brave://history in the Tor window, it might confuse users into thinking that their private browsing history has been recorded on their local disk.
Don't you think so the same? Replace the same content with `brave://downloads:

```
 If we were to open brave://downloads in the Tor window, it might confuse users into thinking that their private download history has been recorded on their local disk.
```
Note: Download history isn't saved, please check your statement too dated 22nd Sept.
